siteMetadata.title: Conversations on agile technical practices and investments

markdownRemark.excerpt: what are criteria in researching communities what are nearby amenities, attractions? when was the houses were commonly built? what are the common building typeâ€¦
markdownRemark.html:
what are criteria in researching communities

  • what are nearby amenities, attractions?

  • when was the houses were commonly built?

  • what are the common building type?

  • what are the zoning regulations? does zoning regulations allows more units per lot?

  • what is the population? what is the population growth?

  • what is the average income in the area?

  • what is the crime rate?

  • what are the rentals supply/demand in the communities?

  • what are the average rents?

  • is it A, B, C, D neighborhood?

  • what are the long-term potential appreciation compared to current returns and cashflow?

  • what is average house prices?

  • what real estate investment strategies could work for this neighborhood?

  • whatâ€™s the prompt for AI to get more information on the communities?

  • youâ€™re an expert in realestate investing, give me detailed outline on the Grovenor neighborhood in Edmonton with the following questions:
    • what are nearby amenities, attractions?
    • when was the houses were commonly built?
    • what are the common building type?
    • what are the zoning regulations? does zoning regulations allows more units per lot?
    • what is the population? what is the population growth?
    • what is the average income in the area?
    • what is the crime rate?
    • what are the rentals supply/demand in the communities?
    • what are the average rents?
    • is it A, B, C, D neighborhood?
    • what are the long-term potential appreciation compared to current returns and cashflow?
    • what is average house prices?
    • what real estate investment strategies could work for this neighborhood?

Ellerslie

Hereâ€™s a comprehensive investorâ€‘style neighborhood outline for Ellerslie in southeast Edmonton, based on the latest publiclyâ€¯available data (~2019â€“2025):

âœ… 1. Nearby amenities & attractions

  • Several small parks and pathway networks throughout the community (City of Edmonton)
  • Nearby Summerside and Walker Park, local playgrounds, and the former Ellerslie Rugby Park (closed 2022) (Wikipedia)
  • Commercial nodes along Ellerslie Road and 91 Street provide grocery stores, banks, fast food, small restaurants, and proximity to South Edmonton and Windermere shopping areas (AreaVibes)

ğŸ—ï¸ 2. When houses were built & common building types

  • Community planned in earlyâ€‘2000s; rapid residential development followed, mostly completed by midâ€‘2010s (City of Edmonton)
  • Building types: ~60â€“66% singleâ€‘family detached; ~20% row/semiâ€‘detached/duplex; ~12â€“15% townhouses; lowâ€‘rise apartments ~5â€“12% (Gimme-Shelter)

ğŸ“ 3. Zoning and density (units per lot)

  • Based on Edmontonâ€™s Area Structure Plan and Neighbourhood Structure Plan, zoning supports low to medium density: Râ€‘1 (single detached), Râ€‘2/Râ€‘3 (semi, duplex) and Râ€¯TH / Râ€¯AD for townhouses/apartments in specific nodes.
  • Most lots are singleâ€‘detached; townhome/duplex zones allow multiple units per lot in designated blocks. Opportunities exist in reâ€‘zoning older lots for infill, but majority built-out under original zoningâ€¯plan (City of Edmonton, Wikipedia)

ğŸ§ 4. Population & growth

  • 2012 municipal census: 5,566 residents, 5.7â€¯% growth since 2009 (Wikipedia)
  • Broader Ellerslie area (including Orchards, Summerside) had ~8,400 residents by 2019 across ~3,000 dwellings (~2.49â€¯kmÂ²) (Gimme-Shelter)

ğŸ’° 5. Average income

  • Median household income ~C$106,400â€”~12% above Alberta average, and ~29% above national average (AreaVibes)

ğŸš¨ 6. Crime rate

  • Overall crime ~11% lower than Edmonton average; raw rate ~5,695 per 100,000 peopleâ€”though Edmonton averages are high in national terms (AreaVibes)

ğŸ˜ï¸ 7. Rental supply & demand

  • Current rental listings in Ellerslie (~19â€“25 active units across types); mix of duplexes, townhouses, condos, basement suites, some singleâ€‘family rental houses (RentFaster.ca)
  • Demand seems modest but steady; many homeowners, but also families and professional renters nearby. Limited supply but data is partial.

ğŸ’µ 8. Average rents

According to RentFaster and Zumper:

  • Duplexes: avg ~$2,216â€¯/mo (ranges ~$2,100â€“2,300)
  • Townhouses: avg ~$1,746â€¯/mo (~1,525â€“1,850)
  • Condos/apartments: ~$1,573â€¯/mo
  • Basements: ~$1,095â€“1,350 (~avgâ€¯$1,222)
  • Houses: ~$2,275 for full singleâ€‘family rental (RentFaster.ca)

ğŸ™ï¸ 9. A/B/C/D Neighborhood Grade

  • Livability score ~66/100 (â€œGoodâ€)
  • Amenities score D (few local amenities), crime grade D, cost of living A, employment A+, housing A, but schools D+ (AreaVibes)
  • Overall this suggests a Bâ€‘range neighborhood: strong housing, income, safety; limited walkable retail/schools.

ğŸ“Š 10. House prices & appreciation potential

  • Specific median sale price data not in public summary; market listed by some sources as â€œn/aâ€ (AreaVibes)
  • Comparatively newer suburban southeast area, moderateâ€‘toâ€‘strong longâ€‘term appeal tied to Windermere expansion, proximity to Anthony Henday, growing population.
  • Likely price growth in line with Edmonton suburban avg (~3â€“5% annually), with upside via infill or densification.

ğŸ’¡ 11. Investment strategies

âœ… A. Value-add / infill

  • Acquire older singleâ€‘family on standard lots and apply for rezoning/infill (duplex, townhome) to increase density and cashflow.

âœ… B. New-build rental or townhomes

  • Develop small multiâ€‘unit infill. New units in townhome form can command $1,700â€“2,200+/mo.

âœ… C. Longâ€‘term hold (buy & hold single family)

  • With median income and low vacancy rates, rent well. Stable moderate cashflow if leveraged.

âœ… D. BRRRR strategy on basement suites

  • Purchase single-family, add legal basement rental suite; collect basement rent (~$1,200) while long-term tenants upstairs.

âœ… E. Multi-family rental block

  • Invest in or develop low-rise apartment units in designated zones near transit corridors or commercial nodes.

ğŸ“‹ Summary Table

Topic Snapshot
Population (2019 est) ~8,400
Growth rate (2009â€“12) ~5.7â€¯%
Housing stock ~60% detached, ~20% semi/row, ~12â€“15% townhouse, 5â€“12% apartments
Avg rent (townhouse) ~$1,750â€¯/mo
Median income ~$106,400/year
Crime ~11% under city avg
Neighborhood grade B overall
Zoning Low to mid density; infill possible
Investment fit Infill, small multi-unit, hold & rent, BRRRR

ğŸ” Recommend next steps

  • Get updated MLS data for recent sold house prices (~2024â€“25).
  • Obtain City of Edmonton zoning maps and property-specific zoning to evaluate infill permissions.
  • Review transit access (future LRT plans) and commercial development pipeline in Ellerslie and Windermere.
  • Survey vacancy & rent listings over three months to validate demand.

Grovenor

Hereâ€™s a comprehensive investorâ€‘style overview of Grovenor, a mature neighbourhood in west Edmonton, based on upâ€‘toâ€‘date data into midâ€‘2025:

ğŸ™ï¸ 1. Nearby amenities & attractions

  • MacKinnon Ravine lies just south of Grovenor, offering direct access to walking and cycling trails leading into the Northâ€¯Saskatchewan River Valley Park system (City of Edmonton).
  • Commercial services and shops are concentrated along Stony Plain Road and 149â€¯Street, including cafes, restaurants, small clinics and boutique retail (City of Edmonton).
  • Nearby major attractions include Telus World of Science, Heritage Amphitheatre, Earth Sciences Museum, Clare Drake Arena â€” accessible within minutes to the east (AreaVibes).

ğŸ—ï¸ 2. Housing age & development timeline

  • Initial residential development began around 1907â€“1910, with many early homes built preâ€‘WWII, around 18% by 1945; most construction was completed by 1980 (Wikipedia).
  • Redevelopment and infill have continued in recent decades, especially along Stony Plain Road (City of Edmonton).

ğŸ¡ 3. Common building types

  • Predominantly singleâ€‘detached homes (~88%), with duplexes (~9%) and row houses (~3%); almost 77% ownerâ€‘occupied, remainder rented (Wikipedia).

ğŸ“ 4. Zoning and density opportunities

  • As a mature area, Grovenor is zoned for lowâ€‘density residential (single detached, duplex, lowâ€‘rise infill). Existing duplexes and lowâ€‘rise apartments reflect midâ€‘century inâ€‘fill (City of Edmonton).
  • Rezoning older parcels for duplex or multiâ€‘unit infill is possible, especially where redevelopment is allowed under the Cityâ€™s Mature Neighbourhood Overlay.

ğŸ‘¥ 5. Population & growth

  • According to Edmontonâ€™s municipal census: 2,362 residents in 2012, representing a 12% growth from 2009, at 2,567â€¯people/kmÂ² in a 0.92â€¯kmÂ² area (Wikipedia).
  • More recent data (midâ€‘2025) estimates population around 2,231â€”a slight decline or estimate variance; household mix: ~35% single persons, 58% families, 65% owners vs 35% renters (Wahi).

ğŸ’° 6. Average household income

  • Median household income around C$104,000, ~10% above Alberta average (AreaVibes).
  • Another source estimates average household income ~C$146,800, reflecting likely newer or higherâ€‘earning households as of midâ€‘2025 (Wahi).

ğŸš¨ 7. Crime rate

  • Estimated total crime rate ~5,049 per 100,000, around 20% higher than Canada average, but still ~20% below Alberta average (AreaVibes).
  • Violent crime slightly lower than national average; chance of any crime ~1 in 20 annually (AreaVibes).

ğŸ˜ï¸ 8. Rental supply & demand

  • Active rental listings remain limited: only a handful of apartments, basement units and townhouse rentals visible (e.g. 4 on Zillow) (Zillow).
  • Demand seems steady for small units given proximity to the core and ravine access; limited rental stock supports moderate demand.

ğŸ’µ 9. Average rents

  • Zumper average rent overall ~C$1,465/month:

    • 1â€‘bed: ~$1,094
    • 2â€‘bed: ~$1,600
    • 3â€‘bed: ~$2,299/month (Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).

  • HonestDoor estimates average rent ~C$2,668 (likely including houses/condos) as of Julyâ€¯2025 (HonestDoor).

ğŸ˜ï¸ 10. Neighborhood Grade (A/B/C/D)

  • Livability rated ~86/100, strong on amenities, housing, employment; crime gets D+, cost of living B, overall housing Aâ€‘, schools and safety rated A+ by Areavibes also (AreaVibes).
  • Overall this positions Grovenor as a strong Bâ€‘grade to lowâ€‘A neighbourhood: established, mature, safe with slightly above average income and housing value.

ğŸ“ˆ 11. Average house prices & appreciation potential

  • Recent median sale price in 2021â€“22: ~C$400,000 (e.g. ~1,000â€¯sqâ€¯ft bungalow built in 1955) with individual sales from ~C$250k to C$1.15M (Schmidt Realty Group).
  • HonestDoor 2025 average price ~C$553,000, down ~1.8% from previous month, with ~$428/sqâ€¯ft sale rate (HonestDoor).
  • Appreciation: Properties in Grovenor typically steady longâ€‘term growth, buoyed by mature location, infill potential, and coreâ€‘area attraction; modest rental yields vs appreciation from price growth.

ğŸ§° 12. Investment strategies that fit Grovenor

âœ… A. Infill / Build-Down

  • Convert older singleâ€‘family homes by adding legal basement suites or secondary units for rental income.

âœ… B. Duplex / Triplex redevelopment

  • Acquire aging homes and subdivide or redevelop into duplex or small mutiâ€‘unit under mature neighbourhood guidelinesâ€”subject to zoning and overlay approvals.

âœ… C. Buyâ€‘andâ€‘hold single-family

  • Higherâ€‘income neighbourhood supports stable rental income (~C$2.6k for condos; lower for apartments). Good longâ€‘term appreciation, modest cap rate.

âœ… D. Small-scale condos or townhomes

  • Target infill parcels or redevelopment along Stony Plain Road corridors for lowâ€‘rise multiâ€‘unit projects targeting professionals.

âœ… E. Renovate and flip

  • Due to mix of older dwellings, cosmetic renovation and modernization can yield returns, especially if resale targets >C$550k.

ğŸ“‹ Summary Table

Topic Snapshot
Population (2025 est.) ~2,200â€“2,400
Growth (2009â€“12) ~12%
Housing stock ~88% single-detached, ~9% duplex, ~3% row-houses
Median income $104â€¯kâ€“146â€¯k
Crime ~5,049/100k (lowâ€‘moderate), ~1 in 20 chance
Avg rent ~$1,100â€“2,300 (depending on type)
Housing values (2025) avg ~$553k; median ~$400k (2021)
Livability grade Bâ€‘ to Aâ€‘ overall
Zoning Low-density; infill possible under mature overlay

ğŸ” Recommended Next Steps

  1. Pull recent MLS sales (2023â€“25) for Grovenor for accurate median sale prices per dwelling type.
  2. Review City of Edmonton zoning maps, Mature Neighbourhood Overlay rules, and infill permitting processes.
  3. Pull Edmonton Police crime mapping for fine-grained trends in Grovenor (NextHome, City of Edmonton, Wikipedia, AreaVibes, Schmidt Realty Group, AreaVibes, Edmonton Police Service).
  4. Analyze rental market trends over the past 12 months from CMHC or rental platforms.

Belmead

Hereâ€™s a comprehensive investor-focused overview of Belmead, a mature west Edmonton neighbourhood, with detailed answers to your questions:

ğŸ˜ï¸ 1. Nearby Amenities & Attractions

  • West Edmonton Mall, Canadaâ€™s largest mall, lies just east â€” less than 5â€¯minutes away by car with major retail, entertainment, and restaurants nearby (Wikipedia).
  • Local parks, playgrounds, schools, and community league facilities are dispersed throughout the area, supporting family living (Wikipedia, City of Edmonton).
  • Easy access to Anthony Henday Drive (Highway 216) gives direct access to the Edmonton International Airport and southern parts of the city (Wikipedia).

ğŸ—ï¸ 2. Housing Age & Development Timeline

  • Development began in the 1960s (approx. 6.3% of units), followed by heavy growth in the 1970s (~60%) (Wikipedia).
  • Additional construction occurred through the 1980s (~19%) and 1990s (~13%), making it a largely mature residential area with most homes built by 1999 (Wikipedia).

ğŸ¡ 3. Common Building Types

  • As per 2005 data: about 50% singleâ€‘detached houses, 36% row houses, 9â€“10% low-rise apartments, and ~5% duplex/triplex units (censusdocs.edmonton.ca).
  • Owner-occupancy stands at around 72%, with 28% rental units (Wikipedia).

ğŸ“ 4. Zoning & Density Potential

  • Planned under the Belmead Neighbourhood Structure Plan (1981 ASP) with emphasis on efficient higher density vs surroundings, especially clustering multi-unit structures near transit corridors (City of Edmonton).
  • Predominantly low to medium density zoning (single detached, row housing, low-rise apartments); potential exists for infill redevelopment or multiâ€‘unit conversions in specific zones, subject to City overlay rules.

ğŸ‘¥ 5. Population & Growth

  • 2012 municipal census recorded 4,603 residents in 1.28â€¯kmÂ² â€” at ~3,596 per kmÂ², representing ~2.6% growth since 2009 (Wikipedia).
  • The 2019 estimate shows ~3,810 residents across ~1,450 dwellings (some variation in data sets) (Gimme-Shelter).
  • Broadly stable population, moderate turnover â€” typical mobility with ~10% moving in last year, ~18% in past 3 years (BeechWoolger).

ğŸ’° 6. Average Household Income

  • Median household income ~C$83,500 (about 12% below Alberta average, slightly above national average) (AreaVibes).

ğŸš¨ 7. Crime Rate

  • Overall crime rate 6,706 per 100,000 residents, approx. 5% higher than Edmonton average, and 59% above Canadian average (AreaVibes).
  • Personal risk estimated at 1 in 15 chance of being a victim annually (AreaVibes).

ğŸ˜ï¸ 8. Rental Supply & Demand

  • Rental listings include a selection of apartments and rowâ€‘houses; Zumper lists about 25 active listings (mostly 2â€‘3 bed units) (Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).
  • Demand steady but moderateâ€”supportive of affordable workers/families rather than premium segments; rental supply adequate for this demographic.

ğŸ’µ 9. Average Rents

  • Average rent for 3-bedroom apartments about C$1,396/month (Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).
  • Smaller units (1â€“2â€¯bed) likely range from C$1,000â€“1,300/month, consistent with broader westâ€‘end Edmonton pricing.

ğŸ… 10. Neighborhood Grade

  • Livability score: 83/100 (considered exceptional) (HonestDoor, AreaVibes).
  • Housing described as â€œvery affordable with above average appreciation potentialâ€ (AreaVibes).
  • However crime is a weakness, rated F-crime in Areavibes data. Cost of living is low (A), employment B, overall housing affordability good.
  • Grade: Bâ€‘range â€” affordable and family-oriented, but with elevated crime relative to city.

ğŸ  11. Average House Prices & Appreciation Potential

  • As of Julyâ€¯2025, 12 active listings, average asking price ~C$383,700, mean listing price ~$283/sqâ€¯ft across ~1,271â€¯sqâ€¯ft homes (AreaVibes, edmontonhomes.ca).
  • Sale prices span ~C$110k to $700k, reflecting mix of condos, row-houses and detached homes (edmontonhomes.ca).
  • Historically appreciation is steady and moderate, with higher potential upside via row-house or townhouse conversions.
  • Good cash flow potential due to lower purchase prices and affordable rents yielding reasonable cap rates for investors.

ğŸ§° 12. Investment Strategies

A. Buyâ€‘andâ€‘Hold Detached or Row-Houses

  • Affordable entry (midâ€‘$300k), stable rental return (approx. $1,300â€“1,400/mo for 3-bed units) offers moderately positive cash flow.

B. BRRRR or Legal Basement Suites

  • Buying a detached or rowâ€home, renovating and adding a legal basement suite can boost rental income and value.

C. Small Multiâ€‘unit or Townhouse Redevelopment

  • Under NSP and zoning, possible to acquire older units and redevelop into row housing or low-rise townhouses to increase density and yield.

D. Entry-level Rentals Targeting Young Families/Professionals

  • With average income below city average, lowerâ€‘cost 2â€‘3 bedroom rentals appeal to middle-income households, students, and entry workers.

ğŸ“‹ Summary Table

Topic Snapshot
Population (2019â€“12) ~3,800â€“4,600
Growth (2009â€“12) ~2.6%
Housing mix ~50% detached, 36% row houses, ~10% apartments
Median income C$83,500
Crime ~6,706/100k; ~1 in 15 personal risk
Avg rent (3â€‘bed apt) ~$1,396/mo
Listing price (2025 avg) $383,700 ($283/sqâ€¯ft)
Neighborhood grade Bâ€‘ (livability high; crime relative weakness)
Zoning Lowâ€‘medium density; NSP allows multiâ€‘unit near transit corridors

ğŸ¯ Recommended Next Steps

  1. Pull current MLS sales & rent comparables (2023â€“25) for updated price per housing type.
  2. Download Belmead Neighbourhood Structure Plan & zoning maps to explore redevelopment allowance and infill density.
  3. Assess local crime mapping via Edmonton Police Service for trends and hotspots.
  4. Track rental vacancy & average rent trends via CMHC or rental platforms over recent 12 months.

ğŸ¯ Final Thoughts

Belmead is a value-oriented, family-friendly neighbourhood with strong occupancy, affordable housing, and solid rental demand. While crime is elevated relative to city norms, residents benefit from close proximity to West Edmonton Mall, convenient transit routes, and a built environment supportive of infill redevelopment and density upgrades. For investors: good opportunity for cash flow entry, valueâ€‘add via suite conversions or row-house infill, and potential for moderate appreciation tied to mature westâ€‘Edmonton growth dynamics.

Let me know if youâ€™d like comparison to adjacent areas like La Perle or Elmwood, property-by-property rental yield models, or zoning parcel lookup data!

Kilkenny

Hereâ€™s an investorâ€‘focused profile of Kilkenny, a mature northeast Edmonton neighbourhood, updated through midâ€‘2025:

ğŸ™ï¸ 1. Nearby Amenities & Attractions

  • Serviced by Londonderry Mall just south in Kildare, plus North Town Centre & Northgate Centre nearby. Also on-site Londonderry Fitness & Leisure Centre, playfields, and athletic grounds within Kilkenny (Wikipedia).
  • Parks include Kilkenny Park, G. Edmund Kelly Park, spray park, and well-connected school grounds (AreaVibes).

ğŸ—ï¸ 2. Housing Age & Development Timeline

  • Development largely occurred in the 1960s (â‰ˆ51%) and 1970s (â‰ˆ23%), with most build-out completed by 1990 (Wikipedia, City of Edmonton).

ğŸ¡ 3. Common Building Types

  • Of all dwellings: ~60% singleâ€‘detached houses, ~30% low-rise apartments, and ~10% row houses; duplexes/triplexes negligible (<1%) (Wikipedia).
  • Ownerâ€‘occupancy ~62%, rental ~38% (Wikipedia).

ğŸ“ 4. Zoning & Density Potential

  • Zoned for low to medium density residential. Dominated by single-family zoning, with pockets of rowâ€‘housing and lowâ€‘rise apartments.
  • Some potential exists for infill or small multi-unit redevelopments within the mature Londonderry overlayâ€”but mass densification is limited without rezoning (Wikipedia).

ğŸ‘¥ 5. Population & Growth

  • 2012 municipal census: 5,715 residents in ~1.75â€¯kmÂ², density 3,266/kmÂ². Population declined slightly (â€“1.9%) from 2009 (Wikipedia).
  • More recent estimates: ~4,500 residents in ~1,500 homes (Gimme Shelter) (Gimme-Shelter).
  • Growth is flat to moderate; mobility rates moderate: ~13% moved within 12â€¯months and ~20% within 1â€“3â€¯years (2005 data) (Wikipedia).

ğŸ’° 6. Average Household Income

  • Median household income around C$72,571, ~12% below Canada average and ~23% below Alberta average (AreaVibes).

ğŸš¨ 7. Crime Rate

  • Livability score: 67/100 (â€œGoodâ€).
  • Crime rate: 7,661 per 100,000, about 20% higher than Edmonton average, 81% above national average. Risk of victimization: 1 in 14 annually (AreaVibes).

ğŸ˜ï¸ 8. Rental Supply & Demand

  • Rental listings modest: Zillow shows only 3 current apartment listings, rents between C$1,339â€“1,779 (Zillow).
  • Zumper lists ~25 house rentals across adjacent areas, though few directly in Kilkenny; typical rents ~C$1,300â€“1,400 (Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).

ğŸ’µ 9. Average Rents

  • Small apartments (1â€¯bd) average ~C$1,340â€“1,360/month; larger units (3â€¯bd) around C$1,780/month (Zillow, Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).
  • Little data on row houses, but they are likely similar or slightly more.

ğŸ… 10. Neighborhood Grade

  • Livability 67/100; amenities C, employment C+, cost of living A+, housing B+; crime rated F in Areavibes grading (AreaVibes).
  • Overall, Kilkenny is a Câ€‘ or lower Bâ€‘grade area: affordable housing but higher crime and average incomes.

ğŸ“ˆ 11. Average House Prices & Appreciation Potential

  • MLS listings midâ€‘2025 show townhomes ~C$220k, singleâ€‘family homes C$399â€“435k; apartments as low as C$78â€“81k (Zillow, edmontonrealestate.pro).
  • Overall values remain entry-level relative to Edmonton norm; neighborhood offers modest appreciation but limited upside unless broader area revitalization occurs.

ğŸ§° 12. Investment Strategies

âœ… A. Buyâ€‘andâ€‘Hold Entry-Level Rentals

  • Low acquisition costs (~C$400k) and rents ~C$1,300â€“1,780/mo offer moderate positive cash flow even with elevated risk from crime; good for affordable market tenants.

âœ… B. BRRRR with Basement Suites

  • Legal suites in bungalows can raise total rent income, improving return in lower-priced homes.

âœ… C. Small Infill or Row-House Redevelopment

  • Opportunities where row housing allowed; limited scale but could densify pockets within zoning provisions.

âœ… D. Acquire & Renovate Value Properties

  • Cosmetic upgrades or modest renovation of aging apartments or townhomes could extract value for resale or rent bump.

ğŸ“‹ Summary Table

Topic Snapshot
Population (2012/est) ~5,715 â†’ ~4,500
Growth (2009â€“12) â€“1.9%
Housing mix ~60% SFH, ~30% apartments, ~10% row houses
Median income ~C$72,600
Crime ~7,661/100k; personal risk 1/14
Avg rent (apt/3â€¯bd) C$1,340â€“1,780/mo
Price range (2025) Apt ~C$80k; townhomes ~C$220k; houses ~C$400k
Neighborhood grade C to Bâ€‘
Zoning Low-medium density; limited infill

ğŸ¯ Recommended Next Steps

  1. Pull recent MLS sales and rent comps (2023â€“25) for price-to-rent cap yield insights.
  2. Examine City of Edmonton zoning maps and the Northmount/Londonderry plans to discover infill viability.
  3. Review EPS crime mapping portal for block-by-block trends and hotspots (Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses, Wikipedia, Wikipedia, AreaVibes, AreaVibes).
  4. Analyze vacancy & rent trends through CMHC or platform data for rental demand clarity.

ğŸ¯ Final Thoughts

Kilkenny presents a budget-friendly entry point for investors targeting stable rents and modest returns. While crime rates and below-average income dampen appeal, the low property prices combined with demand for affordable family housing create cash-flow opportunities. Best suited for investors interested in value-add via suites or renovations, or long-term hold in an affordable mature area with limited appreciation potential.

Let me know if youâ€™d like comparisons with nearby NE mature neighbourhoods like Kildare or Evansdale, or help modeling yield scenarios!
